description: For Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy protocol.
warning:
Reagents must be made in freshly prepared deionized 0.02-µm filtered water to prevent virus particles being introduced into the samples and causing high blanks.

Stains should always be handled in low light to prevent photodegradation. Because the stains are sensitive to repeated freezing and thawing, the stains should be aliquoted as stock solutions in small volumes.

groups.group_name: Suttle Laboratory of Marine Molecular Microbiology and Virology

authors: Curtis A. Suttle and Jed A. Fuhrman

authors_list.name: Curtis A. Suttle and Jed A. Fuhrman

components.data: For SYBR stains, make a secondary stock by diluting the concentrated dye supplied by the manufacturer 10-fold with 0.02-µm filtered deionized water (dH<sub>2</sub>O) and dispense into polypropylene screw-cap microcentrifuge tubes.
components.name: Description

source_data.annotation: Stains should always be handled in low light to prevent photodegradation. Because the stains are sensitive to repeated freezing and thawing, the stains should be aliquoted as stock solutions in small volumes.

components.data: For Yo-Pro-1, dilute to 50 µM in an aqueous solution of 2 mM NaCN to prevent any microbial growth during the 48-h staining period.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: For Yo-Pro-1, dilute to 50 µM in an aqueous solution of 2 mM NaCN to prevent any microbial growth during the 48-h staining period.

components.data: Stock stain solution
components.name: Section

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 2 of Preparation of reagents
source_data.annotation: Because the fluorescence of the dyes is very pH sensitive, it can be helpful to dilute the stain in TE buffer (pH 8) if processing strongly acid or basic samples (Chan, pers. comm.).
source_data.thread_text: Because the fluorescence of the dyes is very pH sensitive, it can be helpful to dilute the stain in TE buffer (pH 8) if processing strongly acid or basic samples (Chan, pers. comm.).
source_data.body: Because the fluorescence of the dyes is very pH sensitive, it can be helpful to dilute the stain in TE buffer (pH 8) if processing strongly acid or basic samples (Chan, pers. comm.).

components.data: The diluted stains should be stored at –20°C, and ideally should be used within a week.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: The diluted stains should be stored at –20°C, and ideally should be used within a week.

components.data: Stock stain solution
components.name: Section

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 3 of Preparation of reagents
source_data.annotation: The dye should be checked before use to make sure that it has not precipitated or adsorbed to the walls of the storage tube. Adsorption of the stain to the tube walls is minimized when stored in polypropylene.
source_data.thread_text: The dye should be checked before use to make sure that it has not precipitated or adsorbed to the walls of the storage tube. Adsorption of the stain to the tube walls is minimized when stored in polypropylene.
source_data.body: The dye should be checked before use to make sure that it has not precipitated or adsorbed to the walls of the storage tube. Adsorption of the stain to the tube walls is minimized when stored in polypropylene.

components.data: Each filter requires 2 µL SYBR stain; hence, 40 µL dispensed into each tube provides enough stain for 20 filters.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Each filter requires 2 µL SYBR stain; hence, 40 µL dispensed into each tube provides enough stain for 20 filters.

components.data: Stock stain solution
components.name: Section

components.data: For Yo-Pro, freeze 800-µL aliquots for enough dye to stain 10 filters.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: For Yo-Pro, freeze 800-µL aliquots for enough dye to stain 10 filters.

components.data: Stock stain solution
components.name: Section

components.data: Prepare a solution of 50% glycerol and 50% PBS. The solution should be shaken or vortexed to ensure complete mixing, 0.02 µm filtered, and stored as a liquid at –20°C.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Prepare a solution of 50% glycerol and 50% PBS. The solution should be shaken or vortexed to ensure complete mixing, 0.02 µm filtered, and stored as a liquid at –20°C.

components.data: Glycerol/PBS solution
components.name: Section

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 6 of Preparation of reagents
source_data.annotation: Alternatively, for long-term storage, 990 µL of the filtered mixture can be dispensed into microfuge tubes and frozen until ready for use.
source_data.thread_text: Alternatively, for long-term storage, 990 µL of the filtered mixture can be dispensed into microfuge tubes and frozen until ready for use.
source_data.body: Alternatively, for long-term storage, 990 µL of the filtered mixture can be dispensed into microfuge tubes and frozen until ready for use.

components.data: Prepare a 10% stock solution of the antifade reagent by diluting 1 g phenylenediamine (PDA) in 10 mL of 0.02-µm filtered autoclaved dH<sub>2</sub>O.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Prepare a 10% stock solution of the antifade reagent by diluting 1 g phenylenediamine (PDA) in 10 mL of 0.02-µm filtered autoclaved dH<sub>2</sub>O.

components.data: Antifade (SYBR only)
components.name: Section

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 7 of Preparation of reagents
source_data.annotation: The PDA should go completely into solution, producing a colorless liquid If the stock solution is tea-colored or darker, it has oxidized and should not be used.
source_data.thread_text: The PDA should go completely into solution, producing a colorless liquid If the stock solution is tea-colored or darker, it has oxidized and should not be used.
source_data.body: The PDA should go completely into solution, producing a colorless liquid If the stock solution is tea-colored or darker, it has oxidized and should not be used.

components.data: Dispense 500-µL aliquots of the working solution into microcentrifuge tubes and store at –20°C to minimize freezing and thawing.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Dispense 500-µL aliquots of the working solution into microcentrifuge tubes and store at –20°C to minimize freezing and thawing.

components.data: Antifade (SYBR only)
components.name: Section

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 8 of Preparation of reagents
source_data.annotation: The frozen reagent should be white; if it has a brownish tint it should not be used. It is possible to use other antifade reagents such as 0.5% (wt/vol) ascorbic acid in 50% (vol/vol) glycerol/PBS or SlowFade (Invitrogen), but they may provide less protection against fading (Noble and Fuhrman 1998). In contrast, DABCO (1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane) in TE/glycerol is reported to be a superior antifade to PDA (Ortmann, pers. comm.).
source_data.thread_text: The frozen reagent should be white; if it has a brownish tint it should not be used. It is possible to use other antifade reagents such as 0.5% (wt/vol) ascorbic acid in 50% (vol/vol) glycerol/PBS or SlowFade (Invitrogen), but they may provide less protection against fading (Noble and Fuhrman 1998). In contrast, DABCO (1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane) in TE/glycerol is reported to be a superior antifade to PDA (Ortmann, pers. comm.).
source_data.body: The frozen reagent should be white; if it has a brownish tint it should not be used. It is possible to use other antifade reagents such as 0.5% (wt/vol) ascorbic acid in 50% (vol/vol) glycerol/PBS or SlowFade (Invitrogen), but they may provide less protection against fading (Noble and Fuhrman 1998). In contrast, DABCO (1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane) in TE/glycerol is reported to be a superior antifade to PDA (Ortmann, pers. comm.).

components.data: Immediately before preparing the slides, make a 0.1% working solution of the antifade by adding the 10% phenylenediamine solution to the glycerol-PBS mixture.
components.name: Description
